circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: Body found in the Atlantic Ocean, 8 miles off Mt. Desert Island. Recovered badly decomposed and partially skeletonized. Possibly from Canada.

conditionOfRemains.name: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction
conditionOfRemains.localizedName: Not recognizable - Decomposing/putrefaction

clothingAndAccessoriesArticles.description:
Dark blue outer "snowmobile" insulated suit with hood, red inner lining, missing front pockets, distal sleeve repaired with silver duct tape. "Made in Canada", size large.
Blue long-sleeved corduroy shirt, Sears brand. "Made in Canada"
Lee brand blue jeans, tear at cuffs, possible waist size 32-34
One gray or blue sock with red trim
One black rubber knee-high boot with red sole, "Made in Czechoslovakia"

physicalFeatureDescriptions.description: Scar just below sternum to just above umbilicus, repaired with a Gortex Graft approx. 2.25 x 5 inches.

physicalFeatureDescriptions.description: Cranial vault sutures may have fused prematurely. Noticeable anterior and posterior "pinching" along with side-to-side asymmetry. When viewed from above, the cranium has a distinct  diamond shape. The right parietal bulge is slightly more anterior than the left. The right and left sides of the cruciform eminence are misaligned.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: ON 11/12/1996 a hunter discovered a cranium near Sebasco Creek on the Sebasco Estates in Phippsburg. A forensic anthropology examination was conducted and revealed the cranium belonged to someone likely aged 18-30, female, probably Caucasoid, and having died between 20 years and 18 months prior to being found. A subsequent canine search of the area did not reveal any other remains.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: On 07/29/2024 York Police Department responded to an area off Shore Road at Bayberry Lane for a report of a bone found on the side of the road near Phillips Cove Beach. The bone was found on the southbound side of the road across the road from the Atlantic Ocean. The previous winter there were several above average storm surges that caused debris from the beach to wash across the roadway to where the bone was found. Bone was transported to Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) for examination by anthropologist who determined the bone to be a human femur.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: White male found by lobsterman in the waters of the Bay of Fundy appx. 4 miles off the shore of Cutler Harbor, Cutler, Maine. No distinguishing features noted. Decedent was found wearing black cotton trousers with belt; white undershorts; Omega waterproof wrist watch (left wrist); blue ankle-height stocking (left foot). Decomposition suggests 2-8 weeks exposure in ocean.
